bestBHT.bht: Within the visible Church, Jesus describes the growth of the kingdom, starting with small beginnings but ultimately becoming universal. Using the analogy of a field with both wheat and tares, symbolizing the righteous and the wicked, Jesus explains that the tares will be gathered and burned, while the wheat will be gathered in His barn, representing the kingdom of heaven. This emphasizes the certainty of the end of the world, likening it to a busy harvest season when the angels will gather everyone for judgment before Christ.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Let both grow together—that is, in the visible Church.
Gather ye together first the tares, and bind them in bundles to burn them.
The growth of the kingdom from the smallest beginnings to ultimate universality.
Archibald T. Robertson: My barn (την αποθηκην μου). See already Matthew 3:12; Matthew 6:26. Granary, storehouse, place for putting things away.
John Gill: Now the end of the world is compared to harvest, because the time of it is fixed and settled; though it is not known when it will be, yet it is as certain as the time of harvest.

As the harvest time is a time of hurry and labour, so will it be in the end of the world, especially with the angels, who will be gathering the elect from the four winds, and all men, to appear before the judgment seat of Christ.
But gather the wheat into my barn; meaning the kingdom of heaven, which is as a garner or repository, in which none but wheat is put, and where it is safe, and lies together.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this passage, Jesus uses the analogy of a field with both wheat and tares to illustrate the growth of the visible Church. He explains that the tares, symbolizing the wicked, must be gathered and burned, while the wheat, symbolizing the righteous, will be collected in His barn, which represents the kingdom of heaven. This highlights the ultimate universality of the kingdom and emphasizes the certainty of the end of the world, which will resemble the harvest season in its hurry and labor. It is in this harvest time that the angels will gather both the elect and all men before the judgment seat of Christ.

Jesus teaches that within the visible Church, the growth of the kingdom begins with small beginnings but will ultimately become universal. He uses the analogy of a field with both wheat and tares, representing the righteous and the wicked. The tares will be gathered and burned, while the wheat will be collected in His barn, symbolizing the kingdom of heaven. This signifies the certainty of the end of the world, which will resemble a busy harvest time, as the angels gather both the elect and all men for judgment before Christ.

Within the visible Church, Jesus describes the growth of the kingdom, starting with small beginnings but ultimately becoming universal. Using the analogy of a field with both wheat and tares, symbolizing the righteous and the wicked, Jesus explains that the tares will be gathered and burned, while the wheat will be gathered in His barn, representing the kingdom of heaven. This emphasizes the certainty of the end of the world, likening it to a busy harvest season when the angels will gather everyone for judgment before Christ.

Within the visible Church, the growth of the kingdom is depicted by Jesus using the analogy of a field with both wheat and tares. While the tares symbolize the wicked who will be gathered and burned, the wheat represents the righteous who will be gathered into His barn, symbolizing the kingdom of heaven. This highlights the certainty of the end of the world, which will bear resemblance to a busy harvest season, with the angels gathering all men for judgment before Christ.

Jesus compares the growth of the visible Church to a field with both wheat and tares. The tares, representing the wicked, will be gathered and burned, while the wheat, symbolizing the righteous, will be collected in His barn, symbolizing the kingdom of heaven. This highlights the certainty of the end of the world, which will resemble a bustling harvest season. During this time, the angels will gather all men for judgment before Christ.
